elements.content: Metal–organic polyhedra (MOPs) are increasingly studied as host–guest capsules, linked into networks, or incorporated into composite materials. As such, understanding the decomposition of MOP structures is of fundamental importance. The degradation of the ubiquitous copper­(II) MOP Cu24[5-(hydroxy)­isophthalate]24 (1) is studied in liquid water. At different intervals of water exposure, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) is performed and stepwise conversion of the MOP into three different coordination polymers is observed. First, the formation of a 2D coordination polymer, 2, is observed, which upon further exposure gives a 1D coordination polymer, 3, and finally a trinuclear copper­(II) complex, 4. Compound 2 is characterized by PXRD owing to its transient nature, while 3 and 4 are characterized crystallographically. The final structure, 4, contains copper­(II) trimers, and so its magnetic behavior is also investigated.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic polyhedra (MOPs) are increasingly studied as host-guest capsules, linked into networks, or incorporated into composite materials. As such, understanding the decomposition of MOP structures is of fundamental importance. The degradation of the ubiquitous copper(II) MOP Cu24[5-(hydroxy)isophthalate]24 (1) is studied in liquid water. At different intervals of water exposure, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) is performed and stepwise conversion of the MOP into three different coordination polymers is observed. First, the formation of a 2D coordination polymer, 2, is observed, which upon further exposure gives a 1D coordination polymer, 3, and finally a trinuclear copper(II) complex, 4. Compound 2 is characterized by PXRD owing to its transient nature, while 3 and 4 are characterized crystallographically. The final structure, 4, contains copper(II) trimers, and so its magnetic behavior is also investigated.

elements.content: The Cu24 isophthalate cuboctahedral metal−organic polyhedron (MOP) is increasingly incorporated into networks and composites. The stability of this unit varies with peripheral functionality. Here, we report the transformation of a hydroxylated version of the Cu24MOP to three successive phases upon immersion in water. Three different coordination polymers are obtained and studied by powder and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The last phase obtained is stable in water indefinitely, has trimeric copper­(II) assemblies, and has been studied magnetically.
elements.clean_text: The Cu24 isophthalate cuboctahedral metal-organic polyhedron (MOP) is increasingly incorporated into networks and composites. The stability of this unit varies with peripheral functionality. Here, we report the transformation of a hydroxylated version of the Cu24MOP to three successive phases upon immersion in water. Three different coordination polymers are obtained and studied by powder and single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The last phase obtained is stable in water indefinitely, has trimeric copper(II) assemblies, and has been studied magnetically.

elements.content: Metal–organic polyhedra (MOPs), also referred to as nanoballs or metal–organic cages, are discrete (0D) units composed of metal ions and organic linkers. They typically enclose a nanoscale cavity with tailorable internal volume in terms of the linker shape/size and metal vertex geometry. MOPs are usually dispersible and functionalizable entities that offer a variety of applications in host–guest chemistry such as gas capture or reaction vessels. One of the most studied MOPs is the cuboctahedron formed by copper carboxylate dimers and isophthalate linkers, Cu24[5-R-1,3-(O2C)2Ph]24. This MOP has been reported with numerous different peripheral functionalities (R groups) on the isophthalate protruding from the cuboctahedron and has been utilized for different applications. For example, the dodecyloxy-terminated MOP-18 has been used by Jung et al. for ion transport through lipid membranes. Zhou et al. reported the Cu24MOP with peripheral triisopropylsilyl groups exhibiting a thermosensitive gate opening, which has applications in gas separation, and MOPs with alkynyl groups exhibiting click reactions and their usage in drug delivery. Park et al. reported azobenzene-functionalized MOPs, which display controlled release of guest molecules in response to light. With control over their assembly, one can design nanostructures with desired properties. These MOPs have been used as supramolecular building blocks being linked by covalent bonds, by coordinative linkages on the axial sites of the copper­(II) dimers, or via noncovalent self-assembly. Additionally, for practical purposes, their solubility and molecular sieving effect is being explored in film fabrication as mixed-matrix membranes. Thus, considering the variety of work being carried out with Cu24MOPs, it is crucial to understand the outcomes of exposure to humidity/water and to recognize degradation products.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic polyhedra (MOPs), also referred to as nanoballs or metal-organic cages, are discrete (0D) units composed of metal ions and organic linkers. They typically enclose a nanoscale cavity with tailorable internal volume in terms of the linker shape/size and metal vertex geometry. MOPs are usually dispersible and functionalizable entities that offer a variety of applications in host-guest chemistry such as gas capture or reaction vessels. One of the most studied MOPs is the cuboctahedron formed by copper carboxylate dimers and isophthalate linkers, Cu24[5-R-1,3-(O2C)2Ph]24. This MOP has been reported with numerous different peripheral functionalities (R groups) on the isophthalate protruding from the cuboctahedron and has been utilized for different applications. For example, the dodecyloxy-terminated MOP-18 has been used by Jung et al. for ion transport through lipid membranes. Zhou et al. reported the Cu24MOP with peripheral triisopropylsilyl groups exhibiting a thermosensitive gate opening, which has applications in gas separation, and MOPs with alkynyl groups exhibiting click reactions and their usage in drug delivery. Park et al. reported azobenzene-functionalized MOPs, which display controlled release of guest molecules in response to light. With control over their assembly, one can design nanostructures with desired properties. These MOPs have been used as supramolecular building blocks being linked by covalent bonds, by coordinative linkages on the axial sites of the copper(II) dimers, or via noncovalent self-assembly. Additionally, for practical purposes, their solubility and molecular sieving effect is being explored in film fabrication as mixed-matrix membranes. Thus, considering the variety of work being carried out with Cu24MOPs, it is crucial to understand the outcomes of exposure to humidity/water and to recognize degradation products.

elements.content: It is known that the parent Cu24MOP core is unstable in water because of hydration of the copper paddlewheel moeity. The kinetic stability of the MOP in water can be modified by peripheral functionalities. One report exists of product characterization of the hydrolytic degradation of the Cu24MOP, a 5-(propargyloxy)­isophthalate analogue, by Mallick et al., where a 2D metal–organic framework (MOF) product is observed. Here, we present the study of the hydrolytic degradation of the Cu24MOP formed with 5-hydroxyisophthalate (L), [Cu24(L)24(H2O)24] (1; ). Three different coordination polymers, [Cu2(L)2((L)2)2] n (2), [Cu2(L)2(H2O)5] n (3), [Cu3­(L)2­(OH)2­(H2O)4]­[Cu0.1(OH)0.2­(H2O)1.8]·4H2O (4), are sequentially isolated and characterized crystallographically (). All three are new compounds, although compound 2 is the hydroxy analogue of the previously reported 2D MOF hydrolysis product of the 5-(propargyloxy)­isophthalate analogue. Compounds 3 and 4 do not have known analogues. Given the increasing study of the Cu24MOP and its derivatives, these compounds provide insights and a reference to assess the degradation of MOP structures. Because 4 shows tricopper­(II) units, its magnetic properties are also studied.
elements.clean_text: It is known that the parent Cu24MOP core is unstable in water because of hydration of the copper paddlewheel moeity. The kinetic stability of the MOP in water can be modified by peripheral functionalities. One report exists of product characterization of the hydrolytic degradation of the Cu24MOP, a 5-(propargyloxy)isophthalate analogue, by Mallick et al., where a 2D metal-organic framework (MOF) product is observed. Here, we present the study of the hydrolytic degradation of the Cu24MOP formed with 5-hydroxyisophthalate (L), [Cu24(L)24(H2O)24] (1; ). Three different coordination polymers, [Cu2(L)2((L)2)2] n  (2), [Cu2(L)2(H2O)5] n  (3), [Cu3(L)2(OH)2(H2O)4][Cu0.1(OH)0.2(H2O)1.8]⋅4H2O (4), are sequentially isolated and characterized crystallographically (). All three are new compounds, although compound 2 is the hydroxy analogue of the previously reported 2D MOF hydrolysis product of the 5-(propargyloxy)isophthalate analogue. Compounds 3 and 4 do not have known analogues. Given the increasing study of the Cu24MOP and its derivatives, these compounds provide insights and a reference to assess the degradation of MOP structures. Because 4 shows tricopper(II) units, its magnetic properties are also studied.

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals were used without any further purification. 1H NMR spectra were performed on a Bruker ADVANCE II 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were measured using a Thermo-Nicolet Nexus 470 spectrometer on a KBr plate. Elemental analysis was performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 series II analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch STA 409 PC Luxx instrument. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku Miniflex II powder X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα X-ray source.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

All commercially available chemicals were used without any further purification. 1H NMR spectra were performed on a Bruker ADVANCE II 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) were measured using a Thermo-Nicolet Nexus 470 spectrometer on a KBr plate. Elemental analysis was performed on a PerkinElmer 2400 series II analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch STA 409 PC Luxx instrument. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku Miniflex II powder X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα X-ray source.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at 173 K on a Nonius CCD diffractometer equipped with an Apex II CCD area-detector diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Crystals were mounted on nylon CryoLoops (Hampton Research) with Paratone-N (Hampton Research). A full sphere of diffraction spots was measured. The data integration and reduction were processed with the INTEGRATE program of the APEX3 software. A multiscan or numerical absorption correction was applied to the collected reflections. Using Olex2, the structure was solved with the ShelXT structure solution program using intrinsic phasing and refined with the ShelXL refinement package using least-squares minimization. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The water hydrogen atoms were located in difference Fourier maps and refined by using the HTAB command. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Structural Studies

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at 173 K on a Nonius CCD diffractometer equipped with an Apex II CCD area-detector diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Crystals were mounted on nylon CryoLoops (Hampton Research) with Paratone-N (Hampton Research). A full sphere of diffraction spots was measured. The data integration and reduction were processed with the INTEGRATE program of the APEX3 software. A multiscan or numerical absorption correction was applied to the collected reflections. Using Olex2, the structure was solved with the ShelXT  structure solution program using intrinsic phasing and refined with the ShelXL  refinement package using least-squares minimization. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The water hydrogen atoms were located in difference Fourier maps and refined by using the HTAB command. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 4 were measured using a Quantum Design XL-7S MPMS superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer. Samples were prepared by placing a weighed quantity of powdered sample into a gelatin capsule, which was inserted into a clear, diamagnetic plastic straw. Temperature-dependent magnetization measurements were conducted in the 300–2 K range under a magnetic field strength of 1 T. Pascal constants were used to account for the diamagnetic contribution to the molecular susceptibility (χD = −350.12 × 10–6 cm3 mol–1).
elements.clean_text:
Magnetism

The magnetic properties of 4 were measured using a Quantum Design XL-7S MPMS superconducting quantum interference device (SQUID) magnetometer. Samples were prepared by placing a weighed quantity of powdered sample into a gelatin capsule, which was inserted into a clear, diamagnetic plastic straw. Temperature-dependent magnetization measurements were conducted in the 300-2 K range under a magnetic field strength of 1 T. Pascal constants were used to account for the diamagnetic contribution to the molecular susceptibility (χD = -350.12 × 10-6 cm3 mol-1).

elements.content: A solution of 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (182 mg, 0.500 mmol) in methanol (3.5 mL) was added to a solution of Cu­(NO3)2·2.5H2O (116 mg, 0.500 mmol) in methanol (7 mL). To this solution was added slowly a noncoordinating base, 2,6-lutidine (0.12 mL, 1.0 mmol). The solution was then treated with excess diethyl ether to yield a blue precipitate, which was gravity-filtered, thoroughly washed with excess acetonitrile (to remove base), and dried to give 1, a MOP powder. The absence of 2,6-lutidine was confirmed by 1H NMR of 1, by degrading the MOPs in a ∼1 M NaOH/D2O solution (see Figure S1), as well as by elemental analysis. Elem anal. Calcd for [C192H96Cu24O120] without including any solvent molecules: C, 39.43; H, 1.65. Found: C, 38.83; H, 1.93. Crystallization: The MOP powder (100 mg) obtained was dissolved in methanol (8 mL) and dimethylacetamide (2 mL) in a 20 mL scintillation vial. The vial was then heated at 75 °C for 2 days. After cooling to room temperature, blue block crystals were obtained whose PXRD (see Figure S2) matched the hydroxylated Cu24MOP reported by Niu et al.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Hydroxylated Cu24MOP, 1 

A solution of 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (182 mg, 0.500 mmol) in methanol (3.5 mL) was added to a solution of Cu(NO3)2⋅2.5H2O (116 mg, 0.500 mmol) in methanol (7 mL). To this solution was added slowly a noncoordinating base, 2,6-lutidine (0.12 mL, 1.0 mmol). The solution was then treated with excess diethyl ether to yield a blue precipitate, which was gravity-filtered, thoroughly washed with excess acetonitrile (to remove base), and dried to give 1, a MOP powder. The absence of 2,6-lutidine was confirmed by 1H NMR of 1, by degrading the MOPs in a ~1 M NaOH/D2O solution (see Figure S1), as well as by elemental analysis. Elem anal. Calcd for [C192H96Cu24O120] without including any solvent molecules: C, 39.43; H, 1.65. Found: C, 38.83; H, 1.93. Crystallization: The MOP powder (100 mg) obtained was dissolved in methanol (8 mL) and dimethylacetamide (2 mL) in a 20 mL scintillation vial. The vial was then heated at 75 °C for 2 days. After cooling to room temperature, blue block crystals were obtained whose PXRD (see Figure S2) matched the hydroxylated Cu24MOP reported by Niu et al.

elements.content: The as-synthesized Cu24MOP powder, 1, was dispersed in distilled water, and transformation into other coordination products was observed through PXRD at different intervals of time. The same solid, 1 (blue powder), aged to 4 (bluish fibrous crystals) in 1 week of water exposure via the formation of 2 (light-blue powder) in 5 min and 3 (blue needlelike crystals) after 3 h of water treatment. The distilled water filtrate obtained during each of the transformations1-to-2, 2-to-3, and 3-to-4was evaporated and dissolved in D2O to be analyzed via 1H NMR. This was done to examine whether the transformation was solid-to-solid or involved any dissolution of the components.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrolysis of 1/Formation of 2-4 

The as-synthesized Cu24MOP powder, 1, was dispersed in distilled water, and transformation into other coordination products was observed through PXRD at different intervals of time. The same solid, 1 (blue powder), aged to 4 (bluish fibrous crystals) in 1 week of water exposure via the formation of 2 (light-blue powder) in 5 min and 3 (blue needlelike crystals) after 3 h of water treatment. The distilled water filtrate obtained during each of the transformations1-to-2, 2-to-3, and 3-to-4was evaporated and dissolved in D2O to be analyzed via 1H NMR. This was done to examine whether the transformation was solid-to-solid or involved any dissolution of the components.

elements.content: Upon soaking of the MOP 1 in distilled water, the sequential transformation from 1 to 4 was monitored via PXRD (), where we also see the presence of mixed-phase intermediate structures. Roughly 20 mg of 1 was used for PXRD analysis and wet with a drop of water. The patterns were collected over 20 min, and so for 2, the pattern would be changing during analysis. TGA (see Figure S7) was also performed under an inert atmosphere showing different heat degradation patterns for the different compounds, i.e., 1–4 ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Upon soaking of the MOP 1 in distilled water, the sequential transformation from 1 to 4 was monitored via PXRD (), where we also see the presence of mixed-phase intermediate structures. Roughly 20 mg of 1 was used for PXRD analysis and wet with a drop of water. The patterns were collected over 20 min, and so for 2, the pattern would be changing during analysis. TGA (see Figure S7) was also performed under an inert atmosphere showing different heat degradation patterns for the different compounds, i.e., 1-4 ().

elements.content: PXRD patterns showing the transformation of MOP 1 to 4 via 2 and 3 upon exposure to water with time.
elements.clean_text: 2  PXRD patterns showing the transformation of MOP 1 to 4 via 2 and 3 upon exposure to water with time.

elements.content: Compound 2, the first degradation product of the MOP, is a transient solid that persists for only about 1 h. In fact, attempts to acquire a higher-resolution pattern were unsuccessful because of degradation of the solid beginning at timeframes as short as 10 min. However, transformation of the cuboctahedral MOP to a Kagome coordination network was previously reported. Moulton et al. reported that dimetal tetracarboxylates [M2L2(O2CR)4] (where M = transition metal and L = ligand), the copper dimer in our case, self-assemble using isophthalate-based linkers to form square and triangular nanoscale secondary building units (nSBUs). The Cu24MOPs form enclosed cuboctahedra using these square and triangular nSBUs. Upon water exposure, the cuboctahedron degrades into triangular nSBUs, which then reconstruct into a 2D Kagome lattice, as documented by Mallick et al. for the 5-propargyloxy-decorated Cu24MOP. This hydrolytic conversion of MOP to a 2D Kagome MOF has also been observed for at least three other Cu24MOPs as well. We propose that a bulk hydroxylated MOP, 1 (synthesized as per Abourahma et al. and crystallized as per Niu et al.; ), converts into a hydroxylated Kagome analogue, 2. Compound 2 is obtained as a crystalline powder having a PXRD pattern very similar to that of the 2D Kagome MOF obtained by Mallick et al. () or by Mohideen et al. These compounds have alkyl ether groups at the 5 position of the isophthalate, and this serves to kinetically enhance the water resistance of the MOPs. Rietveld refinement to obtain a structure of 2 could not be performed because the sample was degrading and further converting during PXRD analysis. However, comparing the experimental d spacings of 2 to those of the simulated Kagome lattice shows some notable correlations. The three low-angle peaks in PXRD of the known Kagome structure correspond to the following Bragg planes, all of which are associated with the Kagome plane: [100], 16.05 Å; [110], 9.27 Å; [200], 8.02 Å. The three lowest-angle peaks in 2, fit to a cell with a = b = 19.6 Å, correspond to d spacings of 16.97, 9.80, and 8.49 Å, respectively, showing a close relationship with the experimental data (see Table S1). The reported analogous crystal structure has trigonal symmetry, and with uncertainty in the PXRD peaks above 2θ = 15° due to sample degradation, the fitting was focused on the low-angle peaks and ab Kagome plane. This strengthens the proposition that 2 consists of a Kagome net with R = OH on the isophthalate groups. The deviation likely comes from the free hydroxyl group, which, while smaller than the propargyl groups, is more likely to interact (via ligation and/or hydrogen bonding) with adjacent layers and cause buckling/strain on the Kagome net. The hydrolytic conversion of 1 to 2 is faster compared to that of other Cu24MOPs because of the small hydrophilic moieties on the MOP 1. TGA also confirms the change in the structure, where the MOP 1 starts to degrade after 245 °C while the corresponding 2D MOF 2 degrades above 275 °C. During the conversion from 1 to 2, the 1H NMR spectrum of the filtered parent solution did not show any ligand, indicating a solid-to-solid conversion.
elements.clean_text: Compound 2, the first degradation product of the MOP, is a transient solid that persists for only about 1 h. In fact, attempts to acquire a higher-resolution pattern were unsuccessful because of degradation of the solid beginning at timeframes as short as 10 min. However, transformation of the cuboctahedral MOP to a Kagome coordination network was previously reported. Moulton et al. reported that dimetal tetracarboxylates [M2L2(O2CR)4] (where M = transition metal and L = ligand), the copper dimer in our case, self-assemble using isophthalate-based linkers to form square and triangular nanoscale secondary building units (nSBUs). The Cu24MOPs form enclosed cuboctahedra using these square and triangular nSBUs. Upon water exposure, the cuboctahedron degrades into triangular nSBUs, which then reconstruct into a 2D Kagome lattice, as documented by Mallick et al. for the 5-propargyloxy-decorated Cu24MOP. This hydrolytic conversion of MOP to a 2D Kagome MOF has also been observed for at least three other Cu24MOPs as well. We propose that a bulk hydroxylated MOP, 1 (synthesized as per Abourahma et al. and crystallized as per Niu et al.; ), converts into a hydroxylated Kagome analogue, 2. Compound 2 is obtained as a crystalline powder having a PXRD pattern very similar to that of the 2D Kagome MOF obtained by Mallick et al. () or by Mohideen et al. These compounds have alkyl ether groups at the 5 position of the isophthalate, and this serves to kinetically enhance the water resistance of the MOPs. Rietveld refinement to obtain a structure of 2 could not be performed because the sample was degrading and further converting during PXRD analysis. However, comparing the experimental d spacings of 2 to those of the simulated Kagome lattice shows some notable correlations. The three low-angle peaks in PXRD of the known Kagome structure correspond to the following Bragg planes, all of which are associated with the Kagome plane: [100], 16.05 Å; [110], 9.27 Å; [200], 8.02 Å. The three lowest-angle peaks in 2, fit to a cell with a = b = 19.6 Å, correspond to d spacings of 16.97, 9.80, and 8.49 Å, respectively, showing a close relationship with the experimental data (see Table S1). The reported analogous crystal structure has trigonal symmetry, and with uncertainty in the PXRD peaks above 2θ = 15° due to sample degradation, the fitting was focused on the low-angle peaks and ab Kagome plane. This strengthens the proposition that 2 consists of a Kagome net with R = OH on the isophthalate groups. The deviation likely comes from the free hydroxyl group, which, while smaller than the propargyl groups, is more likely to interact (via ligation and/or hydrogen bonding) with adjacent layers and cause buckling/strain on the Kagome net. The hydrolytic conversion of 1 to 2 is faster compared to that of other Cu24MOPs because of the small hydrophilic moieties on the MOP 1. TGA also confirms the change in the structure, where the MOP 1 starts to degrade after 245 °C while the corresponding 2D MOF 2 degrades above 275 °C. During the conversion from 1 to 2, the 1H NMR spectrum of the filtered parent solution did not show any ligand, indicating a solid-to-solid conversion.

elements.content: (a) Bottom/black: Simulated PXRD pattern of the Kagome coordination polymer presented in part b. Middle/blue: PXRD pattern of the degradation product of a Cu24MOP with 12 5-hydroxyisophthalates and 12 5-octyloxyisophthalates. Top/red: PXRD pattern of 2 showing a pattern similar to those of the other Kagome structures. (b) Crystal structure of the 2D Kagome MOF reported by Mallick et al. as a decomposition product of the analogous Cu24MOP. Color code: C, gray; O, red; Cu, blue. Hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Bottom/black: Simulated PXRD pattern of the Kagome coordination polymer presented in part b. Middle/blue: PXRD pattern of the degradation product of a Cu24MOP with 12 5-hydroxyisophthalates and 12 5-octyloxyisophthalates. Top/red: PXRD pattern of 2 showing a pattern similar to those of the other Kagome structures. (b) Crystal structure of the 2D Kagome MOF reported by Mallick et al. as a decomposition product of the analogous Cu24MOP. Color code: C, gray; O, red; Cu, blue. Hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Upon further exposure to liquid water for 3 h, 2 transforms into blue needlelike crystals, 3, characterized via single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The conversion here is solid-to-solid because the filtrate did not show the presence of the linker in 1H NMR. Compound 3 is a 1D coordination polymer that crystallizes in the P1̅ space group (see Table S2). It consists of a double-chain structure in which copper­(II) is coordinated to the 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid in square-pyramidal geometry (). Clearly, the copper paddlewheel is transformed and copper­(II) binds to the linker in a monodentate fashion. The structure appears as a zigzag ladder of alternating small and larger steps along the c direction. The small step is formed by a 14-membered ring involving two copper­(II) centers and two isophthalate linkers, each coordinating via one carboxyl group and the hydroxy group. The larger step is formed by four copper­(II) centers and four linkers bridging only through their carboxylate groups. Each pair of hydroxy isophthalate linkers between steps of the ladder orients in the same direction. This orientation is reversed for the next pair. The five-coordinated square-pyramidal geometry of the copper­(II) atom involves both water molecules and isophthalate linkers (right, ). The SQUEEZE procedure was implemented to remove the diffused electron density; thus, hydrogen bonds to noncoordinating solvent molecules cannot be assigned, although they are likely present. Packing of the layers of double chains in the crystal is shown in , where we consider the pink and blue double chains (adjacent and centrosymmetric) present in the main layer. The layers are arranged in such a way that a double chain (green) lies above the empty space between the two double chains in the main layer. Similarly, the layer beneath has the double chain (amber) below the empty space of the main layer, as can be seen in c. The green double chain on the top is oriented the same as the pink one, while the amber chain lying beneath is inverted and is similar to the blue one, offset in the arrangement of the layers one over the other.
elements.clean_text: Upon further exposure to liquid water for 3 h, 2 transforms into blue needlelike crystals, 3, characterized via single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The conversion here is solid-to-solid because the filtrate did not show the presence of the linker in 1H NMR. Compound 3 is a 1D coordination polymer that crystallizes in the P1̅ space group (see Table S2). It consists of a double-chain structure in which copper(II) is coordinated to the 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid in square-pyramidal geometry (). Clearly, the copper paddlewheel is transformed and copper(II) binds to the linker in a monodentate fashion. The structure appears as a zigzag ladder of alternating small and larger steps along the c direction. The small step is formed by a 14-membered ring involving two copper(II) centers and two isophthalate linkers, each coordinating via one carboxyl group and the hydroxy group. The larger step is formed by four copper(II) centers and four linkers bridging only through their carboxylate groups. Each pair of hydroxy isophthalate linkers between steps of the ladder orients in the same direction. This orientation is reversed for the next pair. The five-coordinated square-pyramidal geometry of the copper(II) atom involves both water molecules and isophthalate linkers (right, ). The SQUEEZE procedure was implemented to remove the diffused electron density; thus, hydrogen bonds to noncoordinating solvent molecules cannot be assigned, although they are likely present. Packing of the layers of double chains in the crystal is shown in , where we consider the pink and blue double chains (adjacent and centrosymmetric) present in the main layer. The layers are arranged in such a way that a double chain (green) lies above the empty space between the two double chains in the main layer. Similarly, the layer beneath has the double chain (amber) below the empty space of the main layer, as can be seen in c. The green double chain on the top is oriented the same as the pink one, while the amber chain lying beneath is inverted and is similar to the blue one, offset in the arrangement of the layers one over the other.

elements.content: (Left) Crystal structure of 1D coordination polymer 3 showing the double chains in a row. Hydrogen atoms of benzene and free solvent molecules omitted for clarity. (Right) Copper­(II) coordination showing the square-pyramidal geometry (coordinated to water, three bonds). Color code: Cu, blue; C, gray; O, red; H, off-white.
elements.clean_text: 4  (Left) Crystal structure of 1D coordination polymer 3 showing the double chains in a row. Hydrogen atoms of benzene and free solvent molecules omitted for clarity. (Right) Copper(II) coordination showing the square-pyramidal geometry (coordinated to water, three bonds). Color code: Cu, blue; C, gray; O, red; H, off-white.

elements.content: Crystal packing showing layers of 3 double chains: (a) view of the layers from the top, perpendicular to the ac plane; (b) side view perpendicular to the bc plane; (c) side view from the direction as depicted. Hydrogen atoms and free solvent molecules omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 5  Crystal packing showing layers of 3 double chains: (a) view of the layers from the top, perpendicular to the ac plane; (b) side view perpendicular to the bc plane; (c) side view from the direction as depicted. Hydrogen atoms and free solvent molecules omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Upon further exposure to water for 7 days, 3 transforms to 4. The transformation from 3 to 4 is not solid-to-solid and involves dissolution of the components in water. This is evidenced from the 1H NMR of the water filtrate, which shows 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (see Figure S3). Also, the chemical formula of 4 has a ratio of copper­(II) atom to linker of 3.1:2 and not 1:1 as in 1, 2, or 3. This further indicates that the linker leaches out during the conversion of 3 to 4.
elements.clean_text: Upon further exposure to water for 7 days, 3 transforms to 4. The transformation from 3 to 4 is not solid-to-solid and involves dissolution of the components in water. This is evidenced from the 1H NMR of the water filtrate, which shows 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (see Figure S3). Also, the chemical formula of 4 has a ratio of copper(II) atom to linker of 3.1:2 and not 1:1 as in 1, 2, or 3. This further indicates that the linker leaches out during the conversion of 3 to 4.

elements.content: This final compound is obtained as light-blue feathery crystals and remains stable indefinitely in water, as confirmed by PXRD after 18 months (). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data reveal that 4 is a trinuclear copper­(II) cluster (), crystallized in the P1̅ space group (see Table S2). The composition of the cluster is three copper­(II) ions, two dianionic isophthalates, two bridging hydroxides, and two bridging water molecules. In the structure, one carboxylate group of each linker coordinates, while the other acid group lies free, which is also evidenced from the FT-IR spectrum (∼1722 cm–1 peak; see Figure S6). The central copper­(II) atom of the trimeric complex acts as the center of inversion and is coordinated in octahedral geometry (right, a). The peripheral square-pyramidal copper­(II) atoms are hetero triply bridged to the central atom via the carboxylate groups of the linkers, water molecules, and hydroxyl moieties. Copper­(II) coordination exhibits Jahn–Teller distortions, where the central copper­(II) octahedron has a Cu–O bond length of 2.455 Å (apical-long ones) for central copper­(II) to oxygen from a bridged water molecule, while bond distances of copper­(II) to oxygen from a bridged carboxylate and copper­(II) to oxygen from a bridged hydroxyl are 1.932 and 1.965 Å (basal-short ones), respectively. The peripheral copper­(II) atoms have a square-pyramidal geometry and two coordinated water molecules each. The Cu–O bond lengths of either of the square pyramids are 2.420 Å (apical-long ones) for peripheral copper­(II) to oxygen from a bridged water molecule, while the short basal ones are 1.981(2) and 1.928(1) Å.
elements.clean_text: This final compound is obtained as light-blue feathery crystals and remains stable indefinitely in water, as confirmed by PXRD after 18 months (). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data reveal that 4 is a trinuclear copper(II) cluster (), crystallized in the P1̅ space group (see Table S2). The composition of the cluster is three copper(II) ions, two dianionic isophthalates, two bridging hydroxides, and two bridging water molecules. In the structure, one carboxylate group of each linker coordinates, while the other acid group lies free, which is also evidenced from the FT-IR spectrum (~1722 cm-1 peak; see Figure S6). The central copper(II) atom of the trimeric complex acts as the center of inversion and is coordinated in octahedral geometry (right, a). The peripheral square-pyramidal copper(II) atoms are hetero triply bridged to the central atom via the carboxylate groups of the linkers, water molecules, and hydroxyl moieties. Copper(II) coordination exhibits Jahn-Teller distortions, where the central copper(II) octahedron has a Cu-O bond length of 2.455 Å (apical-long ones) for central copper(II) to oxygen from a bridged water molecule, while bond distances of copper(II) to oxygen from a bridged carboxylate and copper(II) to oxygen from a bridged hydroxyl are 1.932 and 1.965 Å (basal-short ones), respectively. The peripheral copper(II) atoms have a square-pyramidal geometry and two coordinated water molecules each. The Cu-O bond lengths of either of the square pyramids are 2.420 Å (apical-long ones) for peripheral copper(II) to oxygen from a bridged water molecule, while the short basal ones are 1.981(2) and 1.928(1) Å.

elements.content: Crystal structures of 4: (a) (left) Trinuclear copper­(II) unit, view perpendicular to the ac plane and (right) coordination of the central copper­(II) atom α in the trimer showing octahedral geometry and the peripheral copper­(II) atom β showing square-pyramidal geometry. Color code: C, gray; O, red; Cu, blue; H, off-white. (b) Crystal packing, view along the a axis. Free solvent molecules omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 6  Crystal structures of 4: (a) (left) Trinuclear copper(II) unit, view perpendicular to the ac plane and (right) coordination of the central copper(II) atom α in the trimer showing octahedral geometry and the peripheral copper(II) atom β showing square-pyramidal geometry. Color code: C, gray; O, red; Cu, blue; H, off-white. (b) Crystal packing, view along the a axis. Free solvent molecules omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Refinement of the crystal structure shows that a copper atom with 10% occupancy lies between two trinuclear copper­(II) clusters (). This is a coordination defect and indicates that 2 among a group of 11 trinuclear clusters in an array are bonded via copper­(II) coordination. This interstitial copper­(II) has a square-planar coordination geometry and coordinates to hydroxyl moieties in the neighboring clusters with a Cu–O bond distance of 1.865 Å. The coordinated water molecules of the peripheral copper­(II) atoms in the trimer, marked by arrows in , exist as hydroxyls that bind to the interstitial copper­(II) atom with a Cu–O bond distance of 2.050 Å. In the crystal, the copper­(II) trimers pack in such a way that each layer of clusters parallel to the ac plane stack exactly on the top of one another in the b direction, as can be seen in b. Each trinuclear cluster has two free water molecules, and the structure is held together by strong hydrogen-bonding forces, which give water stability to 4 and prevent further transformation in water for the longest time.
elements.clean_text: Refinement of the crystal structure shows that a copper atom with 10% occupancy lies between two trinuclear copper(II) clusters (). This is a coordination defect and indicates that 2 among a group of 11 trinuclear clusters in an array are bonded via copper(II) coordination. This interstitial copper(II) has a square-planar coordination geometry and coordinates to hydroxyl moieties in the neighboring clusters with a Cu-O bond distance of 1.865 Å. The coordinated water molecules of the peripheral copper(II) atoms in the trimer, marked by arrows in , exist as hydroxyls that bind to the interstitial copper(II) atom with a Cu-O bond distance of 2.050 Å. In the crystal, the copper(II) trimers pack in such a way that each layer of clusters parallel to the ac plane stack exactly on the top of one another in the b direction, as can be seen in b. Each trinuclear cluster has two free water molecules, and the structure is held together by strong hydrogen-bonding forces, which give water stability to 4 and prevent further transformation in water for the longest time.

elements.content: Diagram showing the interstitial copper­(II) (translucent) between two trinuclear clusters, having 10% occupancy per trimer. Color code: C, gray; O, red; Cu, blue; H, off-white.

elements.content: The experimental PXRD of 4 seemingly shows an extraneous peak at 2θ = 11.8°, which further intensifies with long exposure in water. This peak is not an impurity and is indeed present in the simulated pattern but with very low intensity (see Figure S5). This peak corresponds to the [002] plane and passes through central copper­(II) atoms of the trimers, along with the interstitial copper­(II) atoms in the array.
elements.clean_text: The experimental PXRD of 4 seemingly shows an extraneous peak at 2θ = 11.8°, which further intensifies with long exposure in water. This peak is not an impurity and is indeed present in the simulated pattern but with very low intensity (see Figure S5). This peak corresponds to the [002] plane and passes through central copper(II) atoms of the trimers, along with the interstitial copper(II) atoms in the array.

elements.content: Compound 4 shows trinuclear copper­(II) clusters, which are interesting because of potential magnetic frustration and, in some cases, can behave as single-molecule magnets (SMMs). SMMs carry information encoded in their spin states, interact differently with magnetic materials, and have potential applications in molecular memory devices. Active research to develop MOF-based SMMs is taking place because MOFs are versatile and can be tuned for the desired structure and properties. The magnetism of the trinuclear paramagnetic copper­(II) species 4 was studied through SQUID magnetometry.
elements.clean_text: Compound 4 shows trinuclear copper(II) clusters, which are interesting because of potential magnetic frustration and, in some cases, can behave as single-molecule magnets (SMMs). SMMs carry information encoded in their spin states, interact differently with magnetic materials, and have potential applications in molecular memory devices. Active research to develop MOF-based SMMs is taking place because MOFs are versatile and can be tuned for the desired structure and properties. The magnetism of the trinuclear paramagnetic copper(II) species 4 was studied through SQUID magnetometry.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of 4 are presented in and were fit to a model for a trinuclear cluster, taking into account intercluster interactions, and (see the Supporting Information for more details, including the Hamiltonian for this system) χ M T = N A μ B 2 g 2 4 k B ⁡ T F ( T ) T − z J ′ F ( T ) + TIP × T F ( T ) = 1 + e J − j / k B T + 10 e 3 J / 2 k B T 1 + e J − j / k B T + 2 e 3 J / 2 k B T where g represents isotropic g values, μB is the Bohr magneton, N A is Avogadro’s number, k B is Boltzmann’s constant, T is the absolute temperature, J is the exchange coupling constant between peripheral and central copper centers, j is the exchange coupling constant between the two peripheral copper centers, and the intermolecular interaction is characterized by zJ′.
elements.clean_text: The magnetic properties of 4 are presented in  and were fit to a model for a trinuclear cluster, taking into account intercluster interactions,  and  (see the Supporting Information for more details, including the Hamiltonian for this system) 1       χ   M   T =     N   A      μ   B    2     g   2     4   k   B     ⁡   T F  ( T )    T - z J ' F  ( T )    + TIP × T      2     F  ( T )  =   1 +   e    J - j  /    k   B   T    + 10   e    3 J  /  2   k   B   T      1 +   e    J - j  /    k   B   T    + 2   e    3 J  /  2   k   B   T         where g represents isotropic g values, μB is the Bohr magneton, N A is Avogadro's number, k B is Boltzmann's constant, T is the absolute temperature, J is the exchange coupling constant between peripheral and central copper centers, j is the exchange coupling constant between the two peripheral copper centers, and the intermolecular interaction is characterized by zJ'.

elements.content: Magnetic properties of 4. The solid line is a fit to a model considering interacting trinuclear copper­(II) complexes (see the text).
elements.clean_text: 8  Magnetic properties of 4. The solid line is a fit to a model considering interacting trinuclear copper(II) complexes (see the text).

elements.content: The most reasonable fit was obtained for J = −13.3(4) cm–1, while constraining j to 0 cm–1, g = 2.24(1), TIP = 1.87(1) × 10–3 cm3 mol–1, and zJ′ = −1.81(12) cm–1. The quality of the fit was deemed to be equivalent whether or not interactions between the end copper­(II) centers were included or not (see Figure S8), illustrating the difficulty in decoupling the J and j parameters. Either way, the modeling indicates weak antiferromagnetic coupling within the trimeric copper­(II) units of 4.
elements.clean_text: The most reasonable fit was obtained for J = -13.3(4) cm-1, while constraining j to 0 cm-1, g = 2.24(1), TIP = 1.87(1) × 10-3 cm3 mol-1, and zJ' = -1.81(12) cm-1. The quality of the fit was deemed to be equivalent whether or not interactions between the end copper(II) centers were included or not (see Figure S8), illustrating the difficulty in decoupling the J and j parameters. Either way, the modeling indicates weak antiferromagnetic coupling within the trimeric copper(II) units of 4.

elements.content: MOPs, and particularly the Cu24 isophthalate cuboctahedra, are increasingly being employed as building units for higher-order assembly and composites. Here, we have characterized three sequential degradation products of the hydroxy analogue of this ubiquitous Cu24MOP, 1. The stabilities of the MOPs are enhanced by peripheral derivatization. For example, functionalization of the 5 position of the isophthalate with an alkyl chain acts as a kinetic barrier and enhances the hydrophobicity of the solids. An alkyl ether group in the 5 position seems neither sterically bulky nor proximal to the copper coordinate bonds; however, we are considering the stability of the solids in which the MOPs are close packed with neighbors, all with 24 modified sites. The MOP 1, with no kinetic barriers, converts to the layered Kagome net 2, with retention of the copper dimers, within minutes of water exposure. For compound 2, which has a reported single-crystal propargyl analogue, the PXRD pattern is similar to a small offset due to a change in the size of the R group. That said, for other derivatives, it is likely that further transformation of the Kagome-type layered structure can occur based on the conversion of 2 within 3 h to the coordination polymer 3, where the copper paddlewheel motif is compromised. Finally, upon standing in water for ∼1 week, compound 4 with tricopper clusters is formed, and this phase persists indefinitely. Overall, from the different coordination products obtained for hydrolytic degradation of the hydroxylated Cu24MOP, 1, one can possibly envisage similar products for different functionalized Cu24MOPs because the building-up mechanism for all Cu24MOPs involves the formation of the same nSBUs. The PXRD peak positions for analogues of 3 and 4 with other isophthalates may not provide highly correlated peaks (as with 2 and the propargyl analogue). However, these structures provide insights for the complex coordination chemistry that can result when MOP structures are employed as materials and provide notice that degradation products beyond the layered Kagome solid are to be expected.
elements.clean_text: MOPs, and particularly the Cu24 isophthalate cuboctahedra, are increasingly being employed as building units for higher-order assembly and composites. Here, we have characterized three sequential degradation products of the hydroxy analogue of this ubiquitous Cu24MOP, 1. The stabilities of the MOPs are enhanced by peripheral derivatization. For example, functionalization of the 5 position of the isophthalate with an alkyl chain acts as a kinetic barrier and enhances the hydrophobicity of the solids. An alkyl ether group in the 5 position seems neither sterically bulky nor proximal to the copper coordinate bonds; however, we are considering the stability of the solids in which the MOPs are close packed with neighbors, all with 24 modified sites. The MOP 1, with no kinetic barriers, converts to the layered Kagome net 2, with retention of the copper dimers, within minutes of water exposure. For compound 2, which has a reported single-crystal propargyl analogue, the PXRD pattern is similar to a small offset due to a change in the size of the R group. That said, for other derivatives, it is likely that further transformation of the Kagome-type layered structure can occur based on the conversion of 2 within 3 h to the coordination polymer 3, where the copper paddlewheel motif is compromised. Finally, upon standing in water for ~1 week, compound 4 with tricopper clusters is formed, and this phase persists indefinitely. Overall, from the different coordination products obtained for hydrolytic degradation of the hydroxylated Cu24MOP, 1, one can possibly envisage similar products for different functionalized Cu24MOPs because the building-up mechanism for all Cu24MOPs involves the formation of the same nSBUs. The PXRD peak positions for analogues of 3 and 4 with other isophthalates may not provide highly correlated peaks (as with 2 and the propargyl analogue). However, these structures provide insights for the complex coordination chemistry that can result when MOP structures are employed as materials and provide notice that degradation products beyond the layered Kagome solid are to be expected.

elements.content: We have demonstrated water stability studies of the hydroxy analogue of the Cu24MOP and its transformation into three subsequent products 2–4 (all new compounds) upon exposure to water. The 2D coordination polymer 2 is obtained as a crystalline powder, while single crystals of 3 and 4 are solved to reveal a 1D chain structure and a trinuclear copper­(II) cluster, respectively, held together via hydrogen bonding. 4 has trimers with paramagnetic copper­(II) atoms that show weak antiferromagnetic coupling. The three new compounds give insights into the decomposition of ubiquitous MOP structures that are increasingly being pursued for material applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have demonstrated water stability studies of the hydroxy analogue of the Cu24MOP and its transformation into three subsequent products 2-4 (all new compounds) upon exposure to water. The 2D coordination polymer 2 is obtained as a crystalline powder, while single crystals of 3 and 4 are solved to reveal a 1D chain structure and a trinuclear copper(II) cluster, respectively, held together via hydrogen bonding. 4 has trimers with paramagnetic copper(II) atoms that show weak antiferromagnetic coupling. The three new compounds give insights into the decomposition of ubiquitous MOP structures that are increasingly being pursued for material applications.

cln_elements.content: A solution of 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (182 mg, 0.500 mmol) in methanol (3.5 mL) was added to a solution of Cu­(NO3)2·2.5H2O (116 mg, 0.500 mmol) in methanol (7 mL). To this solution was added slowly a noncoordinating base, 2,6-lutidine (0.12 mL, 1.0 mmol). The solution was then treated with excess diethyl ether to yield a blue precipitate, which was gravity-filtered, thoroughly washed with excess acetonitrile (to remove base), and dried to give 1, a MOP powder. The absence of 2,6-lutidine was confirmed by 1H NMR of 1, by degrading the MOPs in a ∼1 M NaOH/D2O solution (see Figure S1), as well as by elemental analysis. Elem anal. Calcd for [C192H96Cu24O120] without including any solvent molecules: C, 39.43; H, 1.65. Found: C, 38.83; H, 1.93. Crystallization: The MOP powder (100 mg) obtained was dissolved in methanol (8 mL) and dimethylacetamide (2 mL) in a 20 mL scintillation vial. The vial was then heated at 75 °C for 2 days. After cooling to room temperature, blue block crystals were obtained whose PXRD (see Figure S2) matched the hydroxylated Cu24MOP reported by Niu et al.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Hydroxylated Cu24MOP, 1 

A solution of 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (182 mg, 0.500 mmol) in methanol (3.5 mL) was added to a solution of Cu(NO3)2⋅2.5H2O (116 mg, 0.500 mmol) in methanol (7 mL). To this solution was added slowly a noncoordinating base, 2,6-lutidine (0.12 mL, 1.0 mmol). The solution was then treated with excess diethyl ether to yield a blue precipitate, which was gravity-filtered, thoroughly washed with excess acetonitrile (to remove base), and dried to give 1, a MOP powder. The absence of 2,6-lutidine was confirmed by 1H NMR of 1, by degrading the MOPs in a ~1 M NaOH/D2O solution (see Figure S1), as well as by elemental analysis. Elem anal. Calcd for [C192H96Cu24O120] without including any solvent molecules: C, 39.43; H, 1.65. Found: C, 38.83; H, 1.93. Crystallization: The MOP powder (100 mg) obtained was dissolved in methanol (8 mL) and dimethylacetamide (2 mL) in a 20 mL scintillation vial. The vial was then heated at 75 °C for 2 days. After cooling to room temperature, blue block crystals were obtained whose PXRD (see Figure S2) matched the hydroxylated Cu24MOP reported by Niu et al.

metadata.title:
Three Sequential Hydrolysis Products of the Ubiquitous
Cu24 Isophthalate Metal–Organic Polyhedra
